cmCourseInfo.description: Who belongs? Who governs? Who decides? In this course, you will examine the concepts of citizenship, public space, political membership, civic responsibility, and belonging. You will address topics such as Indigenous sovereignty claims, urban multiculturalism, public housing, and greening the city. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Citizenship in the Canadian City
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, St. Mike's One, Trinity One, Vic One, Woodsworth One

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

Enrolment for Fall/Winter will open during regular course selection periods. For enquiries about the UC One program, please contact Cecille Sioulis at uc.one@utoronto.ca or 416-946-4025. For more information about the UC One program, please visit: https://www.uc.utoronto.ca/programs-study-first-year-program-uc-one

Delivery Instructions

This course will be held online and will have both asynchronous and synchronous elements. For example, some lectures may be delivered asynchronously, while discussions and guest presentations may be held synchronously. Field trips will be held, if public health guidelines allow, and alternate activities will be provided for those who are not able to participate in person. Students are required to have access to a microphone in order to participate in online activities; a camera is also recommended.

cmCourseInfo.description: In this course we learn about different practices of performative engagement with the city and experiment with them through exercises and creative activities. The goal is to gain, through this mode of embodied engagement with the city, a critical understanding of urban space as a diverse social, cultural, and physical environment. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Performing the City I
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, St. Mike's One, Trinity One, Vic One, Woodsworth One

courses.name: Gradients of Health in an Urban Mosaic

cmCourseInfo.description: In this course, you will examine how Toronto’s varied communities access and use health care, and how they may encounter barriers in doing so. You will study how economic disparities, shifting demographics, and government policies affect health policy and the right to access resources. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gradients of Health in an Urban Mosaic
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, St. Mike's One, Trinity One, Vic One, Woodsworth One

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

cmCourseInfo.description: You will learn about the sexual politics of the city and how cities and their neighbourhoods become sexualized and desexualized spaces. In Sex in the City, you will examine what “sex” means to Toronto’s varied, multicultural communities by looking at urban space, cultural productions, law enforcement, safety and health resources and more. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Sex in the City
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Innis One, Munk One, New One, St. Mike's One, Trinity One, Vic One, Woodsworth One

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the American revolution and its reception in the musical “Hamilton.” The American revolution generated multiple stories that included and excluded actors, peoples, perspectives, and more. This course delves into the American revolution and the diversity of those engaged in it and affected by it. The songs, performances, and reception of the musical “Hamilton” are a key resource for exploring the events and role of the American Revolution. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Hamilton: Musical and History

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course is asynchronous and will feature weekly online discussion forums on Quercus. Assignment submissions and all other communication will take place via email. It is recommended that students have access to an internet connection, word-processing software, and a PDF reader.

courses.name: Why Go to University? The Changing Role and Purpose of Higher Education

cmCourseInfo.description: Is higher education about job preparation or about giving students an opportunity to learn about themselves and the world around them? Can higher education in Canada achieve both these aims? This course engages with the spirited conversations and scholarly debates about the ideals of a liberal arts education and how these connect with ancient and contemporary arguments about citizenship. We explore the impact on higher education of globalization and what some call the “corporatization” of universities. Students will be encouraged to think, read, research and write about various models of higher education and explore questions suggested by these debates. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Why Go to University? The Changing Role and Purpose of Higher Education

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is a dual delivery course. Classes will be delivered in person (if public health guidelines allow) or online, with some synchronous live-streamed lectures or other events to enable real-time contact with the professor and classmates.

courses.name: The Construction of Race in America: A History

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will explore the origins of racial categories in America. Drawing on primary sources such as memoirs, film, and government records as well as writings by scholars, we will examine how beliefs about these categories changed over time and with what consequences for the unfolding of American history. Arriving at the present day, we will consider such contradictory developments as the accelerating influence of Black Lives Matter and the headline-grabbing white nationalism on display at the “Unite the Right” rally in Charlottesville, Virginia, August, 2017. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Construction of Race in America: A History

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be held online and will have both asynchronous and synchronous elements. For example, some lectures may be delivered asynchronously, while discussions may be held synchronously. It is recommended that students have access to a microphone and camera to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description:
An opportunity to design an independent research course of study at the 300 level not otherwise available within the Faculty. Normally, students will have a minimum cGPA of 3.0 and have completed 10 FCEs. Permission of a faculty supervisor and approval by the Vice-Prinicipal are required. Those registered in a UC program or UC-registered students should submit a written proposal and application form to the Programs Office (UC173) for approval. Applications for Y and F courses are due by 30 June prior to the academic year; S courses to be submitted by 15 September; Summer proposals are due by 15 February. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.

Application form is available at the University College website at www.uc.utoronto.ca/
cmCourseInfo.title: University College Independent Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions

For 'E' indicator courses: College approval is required. Please contact Khamla Sengthavy for further information at: UC173, Monday to Friday, 9:00am-4:30pm, 416-978-8083, or khamla.sengthavy@utoronto.ca. For more information and for the application form is available on the University College website at: https://www.uc.utoronto.ca/programs-study-academic-programs-independent-study Eligibility: Open to students registered at University College or students registered in one of the five College programs. Minimum cGPA of 3.0 by the start of the semester of the project.

Delivery Instructions

Students who receive permission to conduct an independent study will undertake independent research on their own time, but will also need to meet regularly with their faculty mentor online. If health protocols allow, in-person meetings might also be arranged, but are not required.
